pros:
Best basic PhD funding in Canada
Good to obtain additional funding (SSHRC, NSERC) 
Can TA a lot to support yourself
Best library system in Canada
Relatively top notch academics in social sciences
Very open minded academic community
City is nice to live in
Canada has a great social system
cons:
PhD students are seen as a commodity--take more of them, get more of that cheap, TAing/teaching workforce
In many departments (mine in particular) PhD students are left with very, very little support and oversight after achieving candidacy. This was a major reason why so many finish in 7-9 years instead of 5. 
Basic PhD stipend and most scholarships are not enough to live above poverty level in Toronto today!
Professors are not rewarded for supervising as much as they are rewarded for publishing. This means many PhD students in my department were very much neglected by their supervisors
The political science department is a bit old school, both in its methods and its faculty. It offers very little training in quantitative research methods and many of the young faculty are only here for a handful of years, till they find a job at a more prestigious US institution. As a result, there are not many tenured professors doing modern poli sci research that can supervise you as so many bounce back to the US after getting tenure.

pros:
Rating a Ph.D. position is tough because it is very dependent on your supervisor. Choose wisely. UofT is full of brilliant supervisors that will guide you and provide the lab conditions and funds you need to conduct your research. Others will only look at you as cheap labor.

UofT has so many wonderful resources: teams helping with student integration, immigration, insurance, etc. Registering and getting started was wonderful.

Graduating from UofT does open a lot of doors.
cons:
The minimum funding package of the ECE department puts you below the poverty line. It is possible, but definitely very hard to make it work. Some supervisors will top your salary if they have enough funds, but not all supervisors have enough funds to do so. 

Management needs to increase Ph.D. minimum funding package to a value above the poverty line. We aren't looking for any luxury, just enough to survive.


Other than that, the Ph.D. journey is a tough one: doing courses and research (with all that encompasses) is no joke, but that is not just UofT: that's all universities.

review_title: AccessAbility Services Department at the University of Toronto Scarborough (UTSC)
pros: Working at AccessAbiltiy Services UTSC as a Disability Consultant is mainly challenging with some rewards. To start with the rewards, you do feel like you’re making a difference for students and it’s a joy to work with most of them and get to know them, the campus is beautiful with a nice trail when you need to unwind, staff are generally laid back across this campus (compared to downtown and UTM), there are good professional development courses/sessions as you’re working in a university, and the benefits and pay are pretty good.
cons:
Leadership is the biggest concern. Both directors have been in the role for 20+ years and are dedicated to belittling and micromanaging their staff and team lead. Ideas are mostly shut down unless they align with management’s ideas, which are outdated. You’ll find that over the last 5 years, all new and older staff have left because of the challenges with leadership. This is something that is well known across the UTSC campus. Due to constant turn over you will have a very high case load for which you get no support. Leadership will ask you to speak to them about case load issues, but when you do, conversations veer towards this being your fault and no changes are made (many staff leave these conversations feeling puzzled). This is somewhat understandable as the turnover is so high and many students are complaining to see a Disability Consultant, but there is little consideration for staff burnout, which is a constant concern among staff. In addition to having a high caseload, leadership will also expect you to participate in programming for students, but this will eat into your time for administrative tasks and there is little consideration for how to manage your case load, prepare, and deliver programming all at the same time. You’ll need to figure out a way to make this work on your own, without dropping the ball on either one. 

There is an expectation that student needs always come before staffs. Appointments are booked weeks (sometimes months) in advance, and if you want to take time off but have a student appointment be ready to be questioned about your motives, ability to do the job, and lack of foresight (why would you book a personal/medical appointment during a day you need to meet with students?). You’ll have to manage your life in a way that you book any time off months in advance. There’s very little room for unexpected time off in this position without pushback from management. Schedules are rigid here and every hour is accounted for, with the front desk setting all your appointments in advance. This is not a position where you have the flexibility to make your own schedule. At some point, each staff comes to the realization that it's not sustainable to stay at AccessAbility. Unfortunately, with the high caseloads and micromanaging, this keeps you so busy it’s hard to network and get out of this department. 

Also, if you have a disability, you will be offered very little support, if any, in this position. This is a bit of an odd feature of this department, since your job is to support students with disabilities and you are in a unionized environment. Leadership has honed a tactful way to deny their own staff accommodations and/or make them jump through so many hoops until they give up. 

If you find yourself in a situation where a student makes a complaint. The initial reaction will be that you are at fault, and you’ll likely be belittled and micromanaged for an undetermined amount of time, with your job security threatened. There is no due process here to investigate student’s concerns and very little support for staff aside from the support you get from other staff who understand how leadership operates and can empathize. 

Lastly, I encourage you to reach out to any of the staff here before you consider submitting your resume to see if any of the points I’ve shared are still issues (staff contacts can be found on the webpage). I write this detailed review as unfortunately many new staff are blind-sided by their experience here and unless you’re part of the UTSC community, you won’t know any better (almost all new hires are external, very few  staff (if any) internally want to be a part of this department). Unfortunately, many people across the university know the challenges with the leadership in this office, but for some reason leadership continues to be untouched/unchanged, even in a unionized environment. For this reason, I would encourage you to exercise caution when considering this specific department at UTSC.

pros:
Really fun projects in space sector. There are a lot of companies now that do work in space (MDA, Kepler, RocketLab,...), but this is the place to go if you want to work on small satellites.

This place is a lab under the University of Toronto. The base salary is very low, but the benefits and pension make up for it somewhat. Basically, you're working here because you have an interest in space tech. The Director will take you out to Michelin restaurants every now and then too.
cons:
By far one of the most toxic work cultures I've witnessed and the high turnover shows. The company lost about 20% of it's workforce to bigger companies over the Pandemic. A lot of people are overworked and many have gone on sick leave. 

There is also zero upward mobility because the senior people are there to ride out their Sunshine List salary. Some of the grandfathered employees go mountaineering 2-3 months of the year. Some are just here for the cushy pension and getting a discount of their kid's University tuition. 

The ship has definitely sailed on this place now that so many other space options exist in Canada and globally.

review_title: Do a post-doctoral fellow only if you are serious about academia.
job_title: Post Doctoral Fellow in Toronto, ON
pros: Exposure to cutting edge technology and top scientists. Can attend networking events and presentations hosted in the MaRS building (for example) to explore job opportunities. Located in downtown Toronto (unless you are at the Mississauga or Scarborough campus) so easy to commute without a car. A lot of entertainment and restaurants are located nearby.
cons: Dead end position if you are not serious about academia. Get out quickly because most employers do not value post-doc experience. Even if you are serious about academia, it can lead to a multi-year "perma-doc" role with little chance of meaningful academic employment. Very low pay considering the cost of living in Toronto. Your classmates who went to industry will be making double or triple your salary.

review_title: Flexible hours, great networking / leadership  benefits
pros: Small faculty and therefore small team where everyone helps each other out, whether it be school work or staffing for 3 student groups at the open house! The hours are great (you choose your own hours from a shared spreadsheet) and the leadership / networking opportunities are unparalleled (with respect to other faculty or program positions at UofT). You learn how to engage with people, be professional, and importantly, what it means to be a student leader. Training for this role is great - we crash course diversity and equity and go over all the necessary foundations of DEI, as well as practice common answers to common questions to prepare you for your first tour group.
cons: You may not get many hours in during midterms / exam seasons but that's more personal if you choose. You may get interesting questions from students at different events / open houses, but you'll be prepared well before that. If you're nervous talking in front of people, this may be a con for you, but it's great practice!

pros: World class research opportunities, international networking with other academics, and I was lucky to work with a reputable and and kind PhD supervisor. With my own independent efforts I was able to get a great international job with this degree.
cons: Departments are increasingly behaving like PhD factories in exchange for increased funding from the university, producing more PhDs than ever before with little to no career guidance for non-academic jobs. Overall competitive culture among students. The student stipend is far below a liveable income for the City of Toronto, even with TAing. Many departments, including mine, have an average PhD graduation time over 6.5 years, so students need to fight norms just to get out in ~5 years and begin earning a living wage.

review_title: Very low salary + limited resources for career development
pros:
- It is located in Toronto, which is a relatively large and multi-cultural city. 

- There are good faculties and students to collaborate.
cons:
Cons: 

- Compared to top European countries, Canada does not spend so much money on research. Basically, profs fight for little funding and they tend to exploit graduate students and postdocs with very low salary especially those who are not domestic. If your postdoc contract is about to expire, they offer you just minimum postdoc salary (~33k CAD), which is barely enough to survive as a single person in Toronto. The profs are typically very greedy exactly like US ones. Do not be fooled that oh Canada is different from US! 

- As a postdoc, you do NOT have much resources compared to top US/Europe schools. You have to beg for buying a laptop ... You are not given graduate students/interns unless you try to find them. Profs just want to manage you like graduate students and do not care if you end up a low-salary industry job. 

- There is "almost" no research-based industry job in Canada! There are but very few in terms of their scope. You may end up a low-salary unrelated and boring job, which can be done by an undergraduate student. The profs do not care. They just want to put in their CV that they had xx postdocs and xx graduate students. 

- Since government funding is limited, UoT and other Canadian schools tend to admit a huge number of students to obtain tuition fees. It reduces the quality of education significantly and increases housing price .... Again noone cares. UoT admins have a secure high-salary jobs. They are typically from outside academia. It turns out that a huge chunk of UoT budget goes to administration instead of research. That is why researchers' salaries are little compared to top schools. 

- In my opinion, quality of life in Toronto is not that good. There are too many homeless people around and the housing is very expensive. It is relatively safe. Do not be fooled that here it is very different from US. It is almost the same. Very similar in many senses.

- Do not be fooled that immigration is easy in Canada. It is super hard, complicated, and time consuming!

pros:
- professional development courses available through Organizational Development & Learning Centre
- set winter break
- detailed job descriptions
- historical setting (for the most part)
- discounted TTC metropasses
cons:
Very questionable hiring practices; managers are notorious for turning down internal candidates saying they are "not qualified" and hire friends or family members instead. Some departments are known to hire people without posting for the jobs and HR allows this even though it goes against the University policy.
The University touts that it offers flexible work hours but this is all dependent on the manager of the department. In reality the majority of managers do not permit flex time and are not accommodating when it comes to appointments.
Benefits are actually worse than in some other institutions and do not cover costs of medications 100%.
While job descriptions are detailed, new responsibilities are often assigned to and overload employees. When an employee left our department, his responsibilities were assigned to the two of us remaining even though they are not part of our job descriptions and there was no change in job title or compensation for taking on these added responsibilities.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist in Toronto, ON
pros: The University of Toronto offers the stability of a job in academia. It is a particularly large university, located in the heart of Toronto, one of the most diverse cities in the world. Other cultures are welcomed to the University of Toronto. The compensation is reasonable. The colleagues certainly represent the usual academic intelligence. One can always find a good conversation partner, or somebody at the University with a similar background or similar interests. Your role in the University is defined very firmly, so you are never in doubt about what you have to do. Also, it is close to downtown Toronto.
cons: It is a bureaucracy in which it is very difficult to get promoted as not many spaces become open each year. Also, they are not particularly friendly toward international, particularly Chinese, Indian, Eastern European, or African, degrees. You will have to go through your education over again, or pass an equivalency test. Compensation, while reasonable, is not overwhelming. People are not particularly motivated to work, since they do not get fired either way. Also, the University of Toronto is one of the most stingy places you can ever imagine. It took several years for our printer to be replaced, even though the University has an endowment in the billions.
